author: Kathaleen Roberts / Journal Staff Writer
title: The New Mexico Philharmonic’s ‘Bach to Bach!’ provides structural scaffolding
text:
New Mexico Philharmonic oboist Melissa Peña will be a soloist in the orchestra’s upcoming Bach concert.
If Western music is a house, Bach is its cornerstone.
The musicians of the New Mexico Philharmonic will explore that pillar of melody, harmony and rhythm in “Bach to Bach!” next Sunday at the National Hispanic Cultural Center.
The performance is the first of the orchestra’s seasonal Sunday Afternoon Classics series.
Grant Cooper, artistic director and conductor of the West Virginia Symphony, will lead the musicians in playing the Brandenburg Concerto No. 6, the Concerto for Violin and Oboe and the Orchestral Suites Nos. 1 and 4.
“He took a variety of experiences and approaches to experiment with a new kind of music that started in about 1600. We call it the Baroque,” Cooper said in a telephone interview.
By studiously copying the scores of the Italian masters such as Vivaldi, Bach exposed their structure and contrapuntal rules and complexities to create a kind of musical grammar.
The cold math of line plotted against line, note riding against note, voices knitted into voices translated into sounds often held up as the pinnacle of Western music.
Bach also solidified rules of ornamentation that had before been assumed and improvised, codifying the frills and froth associated with the Baroque. The printed scores of both Telemann and Handel lacked any such embellishment.
“On the page, their music looks so simple,” Cooper said, “like a jazz chart; just a sketch.”
If you go
WHAT: “Bach to Bach!” presented by the New Mexico Philharmonic
WHEN: 2 p.m. Oct. 18
WHERE: National Hispanic Cultural Center, 1701 Fourth SW
HOW MUCH: $24-$68. Visit nationalhispaniccenter.org or call 724-4771 The works of Bach provided the structural scaffolding that would later become the sonata.
Presented by the composer to Christian Ludwig, Margrave of Brandenburg-Schwedt in 1721, the Brandenburg Concertos are widely regarded as some of the best orchestral compositions of the era. Each movement contains a contrasting emotional state: joy, sadness, animation.
The Brandenburg reveals Bach crystallizing the concerti grosso form in which the musical material is passed between a small group of soloists and full orchestra.
His Concerto for Oboe and Violin was originally written for two harpsichords, Cooper said. Based on the composer’s notes and letters, musicologists believe he penned a second for oboe and harpsichords, so this one was transcribed from the original.
“It’s a truly wonderful piece that explores the interplay between the two instruments,” he said.
Bach wrote his Orchestral Suites using the French overture form. The majestic opening takes a relatively slow dotted-note rhythm followed by a fast section.
The philharmonic’s violinist Ruxandra Simionescu-Marquardt and oboist Melissa Peña are soloists.
